title: Truckers Are Waiting Longer at Customer Docks, Study Finds
text:
Truckers are spending more time waiting at the loading dock, leading to delays that cut into earnings of trucking companies and drivers and, ultimately, add to consumer costs.

Drivers reported more frequent pickup and delivery delays in 2018 compared with 2014, according to an analysis by the American Transportation Research Institute, a trucking industry group, and said waits of six hours or more jumped 27.4% last year over the earlier survey.

The longer wait times, known in the trucking world as detention, came during the busiest year for freight trucking demand in recent memory, with retailers and manufacturers scrambling to find capacity during a sharp upturn in the U.S. economy.

The results of the report, which surveyed drivers in 2014 and 2018, suggested many of those hard-to-find trucks were tied up in increasingly strained shipping operations, waiting outside the gates of distribution centers or at store loading docks.

“I’ve been in places where 20 or 30 trucks are waiting to get unloaded,” Gionni Ashley, a 43-year-old truck driver from San Antonio, said in an interview.

Mr. Ashley has spent most of his career driving refrigerated trucks loaded with produce and said his wait times last year ranged from between two to three hours to as long as eight. “A lot of times that stuff is coming straight out of the field,” he said, so drivers “have to wait for it to get picked and processed before you get loaded.”

Trucks moved 11.49 billion tons of freight in the U.S. in 2018, up 15.3% from 2014, according to the American Trucking Associations, an industry group.

“Drivers are saying the customers never responded with more docks, more staff, more flexible hours” to pick up or drop off shipments, said Dan Murray, ATRI’s senior vice president.

Although some “enlightened” shippers have changed operations to make them more trucker-friendly, “the majority didn’t,” said Lee Clair, managing partner at consulting firm Transportation and Logistics Advisors LLC. Some adjustments require buy-in from executives outside transportation departments, he said, such as changing when products are shipped to avoid pushing out loads at busy periods.

The delays put added pressure on drivers hustling to pick up their next load. Federal rules limit most truckers to 11 hours of driving in a 14-hour workday, so drivers held up at one stop may speed or drive while tired to make up the time. A 15-minute increase in average dwell time raises the expected crash rate for a truck by 6.2%, according to a 2018 report by the U.S. Transportation Department’s Office of Inspector General.

Most truck drivers get paid by the mile. Many receive hourly detention rates, but trucking companies don’t always charge shippers those fees, and the length of time drivers sit around before the fees begin can vary based on contractual agreements. Driver detention is estimated to cost drivers and trucking companies more than $1 billion annually in lost revenue, according to the 2018 DOT report.

“Detention time or downtime is cutting into your gross money,” said Tommy Wade, 66, of Orleans, Ind., who drove trucks for 40 years before retiring in November.

One finding of the survey was that women often end up waiting more than their male counterparts, with 55% of female drivers in 2018 reporting delays because of actions at a customer facility compared with 47% for men. Female drivers interviewed by the group suggested that men could be more likely to speak out about delays.

“It looks like women are just more patient but the consequences are a financial one and it hits them in the pocketbook,” said Mr. Murray.
